parts.text: Shampoo and conditioner bottles

Shampoo and conditioner bottles are great candidates for recycling! Here‚Äôs the best way to handle them. üß¥

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Switch to solid shampoo and conditioner bars. They work great and completely eliminate plastic packaging.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
A great option! These bottles are typically made from easily recyclable plastic (HDPE). Rinse them out, put the cap back on, and place them in your dry waste bin.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They can be refilled with product from bulk-buy stores if you have access to one.
Bubble wrap

Bubble wrap is fun to pop, but let's see how we can handle it sustainably! ÎΩÅÎΩÅ

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
This is the best option! Keep it and reuse it for shipping your own packages or for safely storing fragile items at home.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
It can be recycled, but it must be bundled with other plastic films/bags. Don't put loose sheets in your recycling as they can jam machinery. Place it in a larger plastic bag with other soft plastics.

‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Request minimal or plastic-free packaging when ordering items online.
Yogurt or curd cups

Those small plastic cups from yogurt or curd add up. Here's the plan: ü•£

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Make your own curd at home or buy it in larger tubs instead of individual cups. This significantly reduces plastic waste.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They are perfect for starting seeds for a small garden or for organizing small items like paper clips and buttons.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
Rinse them thoroughly to remove all food residue and place them in your dry waste bin. Make sure they are completely dry.
Cling film or plastic wrap

Cling film is a problematic plastic that can't be recycled easily. Avoiding it is key. üé¨

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
The best action by far. Use reusable alternatives like beeswax wraps, silicone lids, or simply putting food in a container with a lid.

‚≠ê **REUSE / RECYCLE**
Not possible. Cling film cannot be reused safely and is not accepted in household recycling. It must go in your reject/general waste.
Toothbrushes

Toothbrushes are a tricky plastic item! Here's the best approach. ü¶∑

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
The best action! Switch to a toothbrush made from sustainable materials like bamboo with plant-based bristles.

‚≠ê **REUSE**
Once its job in your mouth is done, a toothbrush is an excellent tool for cleaning grout, scrubbing small items, or cleaning computer keyboards.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
No. Due to the mixed materials (nylon bristles, plastic handle), they cannot be put in your regular recycling bin. They are considered reject waste.
Aerosol cans (deodorant, hairspray)

Aerosol cans are pressurized and need special care! They are a mix of metal and hazardous waste. üí®

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Special Handling)**
They can be recycled, but only when completely empty. DO NOT puncture or crush the can. Place the empty can in your dry waste bin. The metal is valuable.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Opt for non-aerosol alternatives like roll-on deodorants, pump sprays, or solid perfumes.
Wire hangers from dry cleaners

Wire hangers are a classic case for reuse! üëï

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
The absolute best option. Most dry cleaners will happily take them back to reuse. Just collect them and return them on your next visit. This creates a circular system.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
They are metal, but their thin, awkward shape can jam recycling machinery. Reuse is far superior.
Blister packs from pills

Blister packs are a composite material, making them tricky. üíä

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
If possible, ask your pharmacist for medicines in glass or plastic bottles instead of blister packs, though this is often not an option.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE / REUSE**
Not possible in most household recycling systems. The mix of plastic and aluminum foil cannot be easily separated. This should go in your reject/general waste bin.
Nail polish bottles

Nail polish is considered household hazardous waste because of the chemicals. üíÖ

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **SAFE DISPOSAL**
Do not pour it down the drain or throw it in the regular bin. If there's polish left, let it dry out completely by leaving the lid off in a ventilated area. Once completely solid, you can dispose of the closed bottle in your reject waste.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Buy only colors you will use frequently to avoid having many half-used, dried-up bottles.
Junk mail and flyers

That pile of junk mail can be easily managed! üì¨

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Actively unsubscribe from physical mailing lists. Put a 'No Junk Mail' or 'No Flyers' sticker on your mailbox.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
It's all paper! Put it directly into your dry waste collection or give it to the 'raddiwala'.

‚≠ê **REUSE**
Shredded junk mail can be used as packing material.
Cardboard egg cartons

Those cardboard/molded paper pulp egg cartons are eco-friendly! ü•ö

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Compost)**
The best option is to tear them up and add them to your compost bin. They break down easily and add carbon to the mix.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They are perfect for starting seeds or for organizing small, fragile items.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Paper)**
They can also be put in your dry waste bin for paper recycling.
Wrapping paper

Gift wrapping paper can be festive, but often it's not recyclable. üéÅ

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Use reusable options like cloth bags (Furoshiki style), decorated boxes, or even newspaper for a rustic look.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
Carefully unwrap gifts and save the paper to be used again.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
Only simple, plain paper wrap can be recycled. Anything metallic, glossy, or with glitter cannot be recycled and contaminates the paper recycling stream.
Tissue paper and paper towels

Used tissue paper and paper towels are a one-way street to waste. ü§ß

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Use cloth handkerchiefs and washable cloth napkins instead. This is the most sustainable choice.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **COMPOST (Recycle)**
If they are not soiled with chemicals or bodily fluids (like from a bad cold), clean paper towels and tissues can be composted.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
No. The fibers are too short, and they are often contaminated, so they cannot be put in paper recycling.
Old CDs and DVDs

CDs and DVDs are e-waste made of polycarbonate plastic and aluminum. üíø

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Safe Disposal)**
Do not throw them in your regular bin. They need to be taken to an e-waste collection center where they can be properly shredded and the materials recovered.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They make great scare-tapes in gardens to keep birds away, or can be used in various art and craft projects.
Printer ink cartridges

Ink cartridges need to be handled correctly to avoid a mess! üñ®Ô∏è

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Take-back)**
The best option by far. Most printer brands (like HP, Canon) have take-back and recycling programs. You can often drop them off at official stores. Some vendors also refill cartridges for reuse.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Print less! Think before you print and use digital documents whenever possible.
Power cords and cables

That drawer full of mystery cables is e-waste! üîå

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Safe Disposal)**
These are valuable e-waste because of the copper inside. Bundle them up and take them to an e-waste recycler. Do not put them in the regular trash.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
Donate working cables to someone who might need them or sell them at a local electronics market.
Eggshells

Eggshells are a fantastic organic resource for your garden! ü•ö

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Compost)**
The best use! Crush them up and add them to your compost pile. They add valuable calcium to the soil.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
Crushed eggshells can be sprinkled around plants as a natural deterrent for snails and slugs.
Puja or festival flowers

Puja flowers are sacred and should be returned to nature respectfully. üå∫

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE (Compost)**
The most respectful and environmentally friendly option. Add them directly to your home compost bin. Many temples and communities also have dedicated flower composting pits.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They can be dried and used to make natural colors for Holi or potpourri.

‚≠ê **DISPOSAL**
If you must dispose of them, wrap them in paper and put them in your wet waste, not in plastic.
Bones from meat

Bones from cooking need to be handled correctly in your wet waste. ü¶¥

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **SAFE DISPOSAL (Wet Waste)**
Wrap them in paper and place them in your BBMP green bin for wet waste. This prevents them from attracting stray animals if left open and makes collection easier.

‚≠ê **COMPOST**
While they are organic, bones break down extremely slowly in a home compost bin and can attract pests. It's better to send them with your municipal wet waste.
Perfume bottles

Perfume bottles are often quite decorative. Let's find the best use for them. üëÉ

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
They can be cleaned and used as a small vase for a single flower, or as a container for reed diffusers with essential oils.

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
If the bottle is plain glass, it can be recycled. First, ensure it's empty. Remove the plastic spray mechanism and cap, as these are usually not recyclable. The glass bottle can go in your dry waste.

‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Buy larger bottles which use less packaging over time, or find brands that offer refills.
Broken mirrors

Broken or old mirrors are not the same as glass bottles! ü™û

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **SAFE DISPOSAL**
Top priority. The chemical coating on the back of the mirror makes it non-recyclable. If it's broken, wrap it very carefully in thick newspaper or cardboard and label it 'BROKEN MIRROR' to protect sanitation workers. Put it in your reject waste.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
If it's intact, donate it. An old mirror is always useful to someone.
Old towels

Even worn-out towels have one last job to do! üõÄ

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
The best option! Cut them up into smaller, durable cleaning rags for household chores or for washing your car. You can also donate old (but clean) towels to animal shelters, as they are always in high demand.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
Textile recycling is difficult and not widely available. Reuse is far more practical and impactful.
Socks with holes

Even a sock with a hole has a second life! üß¶

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REUSE**
The best option! They make fantastic dust rags, especially for cleaning blinds or tight corners, since you can wear it like a mitt. They are also great for polishing shoes.

‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
Buy higher quality socks that are more durable.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
Not possible in household recycling. Textile recycling is rare and hard to access.
Disposable razors

Disposable razors are a mix of plastic and metal, making them hard to recycle. Here's a better approach. ü™í

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **REDUCE**
The best option! Switch to a reusable safety razor with replaceable steel blades. The initial cost is higher, but it's cheaper and much more sustainable long-term. The blades themselves are recyclable.

‚≠ê **RECYCLE / REUSE**
No. Due to the mixed materials and for safety reasons, disposable razors cannot be recycled in household bins and must go in your reject waste.
Old keys

A handful of old, unused keys can be easily recycled. üîë

‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê **RECYCLE**
Keys are made of valuable brass or other metals. The best option is to collect them and sell them to a scrap metal dealer or 'raddiwala' along with other metal items.

‚≠ê **REUSE**
Can be used for various art and craft projects.
